justification: “The Psychopathy Checklist-Revised (PCL-R) is a psychological assessment tool … and currently the standard method for measuring and identifying psychopathic personality traits in offenders.”
“Participants completed a visually simplified version of the paper-version of a commonly used task … that measures Social Value Orientation across 15 items.”
The authors note that they “completed a battery of economic tasks that assessed various aspects of their social preferences (Dictator Game, Ultimatum Game, and Social Value Orientation).”
The same battery included an “Ultimatum Game” in which participants decided how to split €100, making it one of the tasks “that assessed various aspects of their social preferences.”
Participants then acted as receivers, deciding whether to accept or reject offers; this part of the Ultimatum Game was used to gauge how fair they perceived different offers to be.

measured_by: Set of 2×2 games (Prisoner’s Dilemma, Stag-Hunt, Hawk-Dove, No Conflict)
justification: “Participants also played four different 2×2 games: Prisoner's Dilemma, Stag-Hunt, Hawk-Dove, and No Conflict,” which the authors state were included to assess “economic decision-making” and cooperative behaviour.
